text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to note that the English courts have power to issue interim injunctions unless the parties agree otherwise. The candidate answer explicitly states that the existence of an arbitration clause does not deprive the English court of power to grant or maintain interim relief (Section 1, referencing s.44 Arbitration Act 1996, which grants power to grant interim measures in support of arbitration). While the answer focuses heavily on the *discretion* to use that power in the context of arbitration, it clearly establishes the court's underlying power to grant the injunction.", "criterion_id": "995f6066-187d-4060-8054-7d74054a2def"}
